history.content: Can you elaborate on why you plan on taking both 140 and 126? While neither is a subset of the other, I think if you're taking 70 it's a better use of your time to take 126 (assuming you're comfortable with 70 material) and self-study the remaining 140 material you don't cover in either 70 or 126

children.subject:
Thanks!

I want to take STAT140 and EE126 because 140 fulfils my stats major and 126 is for my ML/AI research later. I'm a freshman, so I think there's lots of time for me to devote myself fully to probability next semester.

I have not taken 140 beyond the week I was in it before dropping. I am currently in 126. While I agree with the students response that's its most likely a better use of your time to take 1 or the other, if you have the time and inclination, I truly believe that taking 140 and then 126 will give you a great and fulfilling understanding of probability and stochastic processes (assuming you put in the time and effort). 140 will grind you on your fundamentals (and imo is the better structured course), and 126 will show you cool applications. If I had the time to do that, I would have. I think the probability in 70 is good enough for 126, especially if you did well, but taking 140 will really set everything in stone. So, its up to your remaining time at this school and if your so inclined as to do it.

I took CS 70 and Stat 140 at the same time last semester (Spring 2020), and found that the probability part (second half) of CS 70 was basically the same as the first half of Stat 140. The 2 classes used slightly different notation and placed emphasis on different parts, but conceptually the content was pretty much the same, so I found that my experience in Stat 140 made the second half of CS 70 a lot easier. For example, I didn't really study for CS 70 Midterm 3 (it was at the end of the semester and essentially replaced the final) but still did well (got in the A range) because I had previously learned and studied the concepts for Stat 140.

<md>Sorry this isn't an answer, but why are you taking 126 "for" grad school? Is it one of those unwritten rules for people applying for as CS that they have to take 126/127/189 instead of just 140 + 189? Or do you feel it would be better prep for the coursework/research in grad school? </md>

Yeah good question. From what I've seen on this Piazza the 126/127/189 trio is the "standard" for grad school. I'm trying to maximize my chances since I'm applying for PhD programs which are insanely competitive so I want to give it all I've got. I've already done 127 and 189 so I figured I might as well do 126 as well. I also took 127 PNP so I'd like a grade for 126 to show some competence in ML (though I know that 127 and 126 are very different). In my research personally, I have found 140 to be pretty sufficient. The most important thing for research honestly hasn't been classes I've taken but the ability to figure things out on your own via reading papers and understanding them (which classes help build the foundation for)

I know not many people do both but if anyone has can you elaborate on taking both 140 and 126? The reason I'd like to is bc I'm a CS/DS double major so I took 140 before I decided to pursue grad school and research in AI/ML (for which I'll need 126 which I plan to take Spring).

history.content: I'm taking CS70 this semester and will be taking STAT140 next semester along with EE126. Just wonder how much content is overlapped between CS70 and STAT140 so that my workload can be reduced.
history.subject: How much overlap between CS70 and STAT140?
